story: PEOPLE across Scotland will be able to catch a glimpse of NASArsquos Space X rocket as it fires into the sky tonight.UPDATE: THE LAUNCH HAS BEEN POSTPONED UNTIL SATURDAYThe launch will be the first manned flight to take off from American soil since  ndash with the world watching eagerly to see how astronauts Robert Behnken and Douglas Hurley fare on their journey to the International Space Station .And the fortunate weather forecasts means we should hopefully be able to view it above us.The SpaceX Falcon  rocket will lt off from the Kennedy Space Centre in Florida at around .pm EDT ndash around .pm UK time.The rocket should be visible over Scotland around  minutes later at around .-.pm.and Douglas Hurley" alt"Border : Astronauts Robert Behnkenand Douglas Hurley" class"editor-image"Astronauts Robert Behnkenand Douglas HurleyProvided there is not much cloud, some places in Scotland will be able to get some great views of the craft with the sky very light.MeteorWatch says the rocket will pass over the country from a westerly direction, heading east.It should be visible for three to four minutes, says the service.It adds: "As the Spacecraft passes over the UK, we may see just the one or a collection of objects looking like bright stars moving across the sky.ldquoThe sky will be fairly light for some especially for observers in places in the north such as Scotland.ldquoThe craft should be bright enough to follow once you catch a glimpse of it."#Nasa is streaming the launch live on Nasa TV, which is available to watch on YouTube at: https:www.youtube watch vAymrnzianf

title: nasa-cancels-rocket-launch-borders-seen
story: NASA has cancelled the launch of a rocket which would have been visible over skies in the Borders.The SpaceX Falcon  rocket had been scheduled to lt offfrom the Kennedy Space Centre in Florida at around .pmon May .But space chiefs have pulled the plug on the launch due to bad weather.NASA published a tweet at .pm ndash minutes before the planned lt-off ndash to noty the expectant world of its decision.The tweet reads: "We are not going to launch today."Due to the weather conditions, the launch is scrubbing."Our next opportunity will be Saturday, May  at :pm ET."Live #LaunchAmerica coverage will begin at am ET."

title: volunteers-plant-colourful-display-innerleithen
story: DESPITE St Ronans Border Games Week being cancelled this year, there will be a blooming marvellous display in the town reminding locals of their historic traditions.At a time when everyone is keeping their hands meticulously clean, volunteers from Bonnie Innerleithen and the Edible Garden were getting theirs dirty to plant the summer display in the flowerbeds at the top of Traquair Road.And the plants werenrsquot the only things that had to be spaced out ndash the green-fingered volunteers had to make sure they kept a safe social distance to adhere to government guidelines.Gordon Daly, Fiona Jack, Julie Waddell and Alex Smithson, along with her family, accomplished a great team effort to weed and place the huge number of plants for both beds.The plants ndash including white snapdragon, cosmos, gypsophila, blue nigella, salvia and Swan River daisies ndash will give a vibrant display of blue and white and will be a welcome reminder of the townrsquos festivities which were cancelled due to coronavirus.This seasons display has been sponsored by Innerleithens Ex Standard Bearers in association with both the community trust and community council.Grown by the children of St Ronans Primary School under the expert supervision of Alex Smithson, from The Edible Garden, the scene promises to be a wonderful splash of colour for the towns High Street.The Edible Garden has been established at St Ronans Primary School for more than five years.It works in partnership with the St Ronans Youth and Community Centre and received money from Scottish Borders CouncilsLocalities Bid Fund last year.The garden provides a venue for learning how to grow fruit and vegetables using organic methods and has a polytunnel, raised beds, and a fruit orchard.All pupils from the school participate in gardening activities, and families are welcomed at the weekly garden club when school is open.Volunteers from the wider community are an essential part of the team that helps gardener Alexandra Smithson maintain the garden.Secretary of Innerleithen Community Council Gordon Daly has been driving the project forward following cuts to seasonal planting displays by SBC.He said: ldquoWith the help of the schools eco committee of pupils we sowed a range of flower seeds that were germinated in classrooms."The young plants were potted up in the garden polytunnel before being planted out in the beds on the High Street."The flowers were chosen to celebrate the Games Week colours of blue and white and also to attract bees and pollinators throughout the summer.

title: fairy-godmothers-visiting-children-borders
story: FAIRY godmothers do exist ndash at least here in the Borders they do.The Scottish Fairy Godmothers is a Facebook page, set up by Borders residents, which offers comfort during lockdown ndash and gts surprises to members.Peebles member Zoe Falconer said: ldquoThe page is for people to have a chat with one another during these hard times."You can create an Amazon gt list and post this on the page and people gt you off this list.The group has now signed up nearly  members throughout the region.Zoe said: ldquoWe decided to make a wish list for the children and we are making up gt bags to deliver throughout June."It is funded by members of the page and all children who are nominated will receive a gt."We wanted to do something nice for youngsters ndash they have accepted all the changes in their lives due to this terrible virus and have adapted really well.With the help of her friend Kathleen Aitchison, Zoe will be delivering gts to more than  children in Peebles alone.Describing how the group has helped since lockdown began, Zoe said: ldquoYou can talk to people and donrsquot feel so alone ndash and itrsquos always nice to get a wee gt through your door.The Scottish Fairy Godmothers was set up by Galashiels resident Jade Nisbet alongside Danielle Johnston from Melrose.

title: scotlands-lockdown-eased-six-things-can-cant-phase-1-begins
story: NICOLA Sturgeon has today confirmed lockdown measures will be eased in Scotland.The First Minister said phase  of the four-phase plan will begin from tomorrow with some "careful but cautious changes" to protocol.Shethanked the Scottish public, saying the fact the changes could be made were down to compliance with lockdown measures.Ms Sturgeon said that a downward trend was ldquosustained and unmistakable.People will also now be allowed to sit and sunbathe in local parks.A legal limit will not be put on how far people will be allowed to travel for recreation but the First Minister said the ldquostrong advice of the Scottish Government was to stay within five miles.Nicola Sturgeon confirms Scotland will now move to Phase One of lting the coronavirus lockdown #Lockdown@NicolaSturgeonpic QvAApfJTmdash Ryan CapperauldMay , What can I do Meeting family and friends:The First Minister confirmed today that as of tomorrow, your household will nowbe able to meet up with another household outdoors.This will need to be in small groups - a maximum of eight.You can meet outdoors and in privategardens, but with social distancing required at all times.Under phase , you will not allowed to meet other households indoors - this will come in phase .The First Minister advised those wanting to have a BBQ with other households to bring their own food and avoid contact with others.Sports and outdoor activityThe easing of restrictions mean as of tomorrow, more outdoor activity will be permitted.This includes sunbathing or sitting in the park, as long as social distancing is maintained.Unrestricted outdoor exercise will continue, with non-contact sport such as golf, hiking, canoeing, outdoor swimming, fishing and bowls all back on the table.Shopping Fast FoodDrive-thru outlets will be allowed tore-open under the new plans.Garden centres and plant nurseries can also reopen with physical distancing.However cafes should not open at this stage - except for takeaway.SchoolsSchool staff are toto the classrooms from Monday - with Nicola Sturgeon confirming all schools in Scotland will reopen from August .The reopening of schools will be ablended model of in-school and at-home learning.From next week, child-minding services can reopen.Transition support will be available for children starting P and S as of next week.WorkAs we move into Phase , remote working remains the "default position" for those who can.For those who have to travel to work, a employers are encouraged to use staggered start times and flexible working.Most outdoor work can begin from tomorrow, with construction work able toresume site preparation.,params: .pushRecycling CentresRecycling centres in Scotland will be allowed to open.What cant I do Pubs RestaurantsUnder the current guidance, pubs and restaurants will not be able to reopen next week.As of phase , which is an unknown date as yet, pubs and restaurants can open their outdoor spaces with physical distancing and increased hygeine routines.Only when we reach phase  will pubs be allowed to open their indoor spaces.RetailersNon-essential shops like fashion retailers will be asked to remain closed at this time.Other householdsYou still cannot enter other households.This means when visiting other gardens, the First Minister encouraged common sense - adding not to travel too far in case you need to use the toilet.Public TransportPublic transport remains limited for essential journeys only.You should not take public transport for exercise or to visit friends outdoors.Visiting beauty spotsThe advice remains on not visiting these areas.The First Minister said: ldquoWe simply donrsquot want, in this phase, large numbers of people at tourist hotspots or beauty spots.ldquoCrowds of people, eventheyrsquore trying to social distance, bring more risk than we judge is acceptable at this point.Contact sports Contact sports, like football and rugby, remain off limits during the current review.Only non-contact sports where physical distancing can be remained are allowed during the new protocol.

title: ryanair-legal-rights-get-refund
story: Ryanair has been named as theworst major airline in the UK for refunding British customers whose flights werecancelled due to Covid-.More than eight out of  customersare still waiting to get their money back for cancellations, according to Which Here is everything you need to know.Is refusing a refund legal EU and UK airlines, such as Ryanair, are legally obligated to issue refunds within seven days of a cancellation.While travel companies are entitled to offer alternatives to a refund, such as a credit note, in the event of cancelled bookings, it is a customerrsquos legal right to be given the option of a full cash refund.However, only five per cent of Ryanair customers surveyed by Which  have reported receiving their money within this time frame.Almost  per cent of Ryanair customers are still waiting to be refunded.This is in stark contrast to rival airline Jet, with only  per cent of customers still awaiting a refund, and  per cent of customers at British Airways.Refunds are also slowly being processed by easyJet, with  per cent of customers still waiting to get their money back.Do I have to accept a voucher Ryanair has come under fire for confusing customers with its numerous changes in approach to refunds and vouchers.The airline initially told customers it was processing refunds at the beginning of the coronavirus outbreak, although many reported that the refund forms did not work.Ryanair then attempted to force vouchers on passengers who had specically requested a refund, and suggested that customers may have to wait as long as  months before getting their money back, according to Which .What has the Civil Aviation Authority said In May, the Civil Aviation Authority warned airlines that the law was clear and customers must be granted a refundthey request it, rather than being offered a voucher or credit note.The CAA said: ldquoUnder the law, consumers are entitled to receive a refund for their cancelled flights.ldquoDespite the challenges the industry is currently facing [...] it is important that consumers are given a clear option to request a cash refund without unnecessary barriers.In a statement, Ryanair said it would offer refunds, but customers may have to wait until the coronavirus crisis is over.The airline said: ldquoThe process time for cash refunds is taking longer due to the fact we are having to process , times the usual volume of cancellations and have fewer staff available due to social distancing measures.ldquoCustomers who choose not to accept a free [booking] move or voucher will be refunded in due course, once this unprecedented crisis is over.How can I make a claim for a refund from Ryanair Customers should visitrefundclaims.ryanairand fill out the attached form.

title: can-visit-recycling-centre-borders
story: BORDERERS will be able to take their rubbish to recycling centres from Monday .But drivers will have to check their car number plates before making the journey.As previously reported, access will be restricted depending on whether a vehicle has an odd or even registration number.And the alternate day system will be enforced for at least the next two weeks, according to Scottish Borders Council .If the last digit of your number plate is zero, two, four, six or eight, you will be able to visit on the following dates:Tuesday, June  Thursday, June  Saturday, June  Monday, June  Wednesday, June  Friday, June  and Sunday, June .Butthe last digit of your number plate is one, three, five, seven or nine, you can gain entry on:Monday, June  Wednesday, June  Friday, June  Sunday, June  Tuesday, June  Thursday, June  and Saturday, June .A council spokesperson said: ldquoResidents are strongly encouraged to visit SBCrsquos website, which will include live queueing times and full details of temporary restrictions at www.scotborders.gov.uk recyclingcentres.Other temporary restrictions include:Recycling centres will be open seven days a week, between am to pmOnly cars and small vans weighing up to two tonnes accepted, such as car-derived vans and small  vans. No large vans, trailers or horse boxes will be acceptedOnly garden waste and waste that residents normally put in their general waste bin will be acceptedMaximum of five bin bags per trip and only one visit allowed per dayIf possible, one person per vehicle should travel to the site and only one should leave the vehicle to offload waste.

title: nasa-spacex-rescheduled-rocket-mission-visible-glasgow--
story: A RESCHEDULED flightof the NASA Space X rocket will be visible across Scotland on Saturday evening.The initial missionwas scrubbed just  minutes before lt-off on Wednesday over weather fears at the Kennedy Space Centre in Cape Canaveral, Florida.The launch will be the first manned flight to take off from American soil since  ndash with the world watching eagerly to see how astronauts Robert Behnken and Douglas Hurley fareon their journey to the International Space Station .And the fortunate weather forecastmeans we should hopefully be able to view it above us.The SpaceX Falcon  rocket will now lt off at around .pm .Unlike the first planned launch, sky gazers in the UK will not be able to see it as it rises into the sky because it will be too light ndash but instead wersquoll see it as it passes overhead.Weather permitting ndash and currently that appears to be on our side ndash the second pass will be visible to anyone facing south-west with a clear view of the horizon.This is expected to be at around .pm.You will be able to track it as it heads over Scotland here.Astrophysicist Dr Darren Baskill told The Independent:"It will look like any other satellite does ndash a spot moving across the sky in  minutes."Because the spaceship is small, it will be faint ndash so fine to see with the unaided eyes, but nowhere near as bright as the football-field sized International Space Station.Nasa is streaming the launch live on Nasa TV, which is available to watch on YouTube here.

title: borders-golfers-rush-back-course-sport-returns
story: BORDERS golf courses are ready for a busy weekend as the sport makes atoday .First Minister Nicola Sturgeon is allowing a number of outdoor sports to take place as long as social distancing guidelines are respected.Golfers have been quick to book up tee times this weekend, with fine weather expected.Torwoodlee chairman Robin Brydon said: ldquoEverybodyrsquos raring to go."Mr Brydon told the Border that the course is "almost fully booked" for the coming days."Everybody on the golf course is ready ndash all the pins are in, and the greens are getting their final cut," said Mr Brydon.He added: ldquoWe had three new members sign up on Wednesdaybecause golf is one of the sports people can play.Melrose Golf Club has also recruited new members, according to greens convenor Gary Craig.He said: ldquoThere has definitely been a decent uptake of tee times by members, and wersquove had a couple of new members joining.ldquoBut it is just members at the moment ndash no visitors are permitted to play.ldquoWersquore expecting more members to keep booking online."Players are expected to tee off  minutes apart, and keep to the two-metre distancing rule ndash or two club s, as we call it!ldquoWe hope people will use their common sense.Melrose residents have been walking the course during lockdown, said Mr Craig, but there are now fears over health and safety as the sport s.Mr Craig said: ldquoThere is a slight concern, because people have been using the course as a public park."Wersquove been putting up signs warning the general public.ldquoWith the gorgeous weather, everybodyrsquos been out.Jedburgh Golf Club, meanwhile, is allowing visitors to play ndash but onlythey live within five miles of the course, so that Scottish Government guidance is followed.The clubs head of committee Chris Paige said: ldquoWersquore asking the question [of where they live] but ultimately it comes down to each inidual, andthey want to follow the rules or not ndash the club can only do so much.ldquoWe have a couple of groups of visitors today and another couple over the weekend.ldquoItrsquos a bit of a boost in income for the club, having been shut for over two months."Visitor income is a huge part of our income.ldquoItrsquos great to welcome them back.

title: tv-celebrity-sends-message-earlston-high-school-pupils
story: EARLSTON High School pupils have been sent encouraging words from a TV celebrity.The X Factorjudge Louis Walsh posted a video message on Twitter today .The Irishman told pupils they should pluck up the courage to enter their school talent show, Earlstons Got Virtual Talent.He said: "Times running out ndash this is a big, big talent show: its called Earlstons Got Virtual Talent."I think youve got virtually a little bit of talent, so amuse us."Youve nothing to lose ndash send in a video."Sing, dance, be funny, play tricks ndash do anything ndash just do something, because youve got the time now to do it."So, come on, just show us what youve got."The pupils had previously been sent a video message from actor Jack Lowden, a former Earlston student.

title: aldi-launch-cooling-mats-stop-cats-dogs-overheating
story: Aldi has launched a new product for pets to stop them overheating and keep them cool during the summer months.The month of May has served as a pleasant reminder to the nation of how glorious the weather can sometimes be in the UK.Last week saw the hottest temperatures of the year so far and many people took to sunbathing in their gardens.To help keep your pet by your side, and feeling cool while you soak up the sun, the discount retailer is selling cooling mats priced from pound..They arepart of a iety of new pet accessories being launched in stores and online as part of the Specialbuys range.When did the pet mats go on sale The supermarket began selling the mats -along with other items in the pets Specialbuys range - on Thursday, May .Proving extremely popular, all of the rangersquos cooling mats have now sold out online at aldi and it is not known when they will be back in stock.However, you can still purchase the mats in store.What mat designs are there The range features ious designs, including a circular watermelon printed mat and a lemon version.The mats can be easily cleaned with wipes and stay dont require any freezing to keep them cool, as they are specically designed to remain at a cool temperature.What  is in the range As part of the pet range, Aldi is also selling a set of three cooling dog toys for pound. which includes a ball, shark and bone.Other items in the range include cooling pet bowls priced at pound. each and a luxury pet bed bundle for pound..Itrsquos worth noting thatyou choose to purchase any items in the range online, you will have to pay a delivery fee of pound.your order is under pound.

title: labour-frontbencher-no-longer-role-lockdown-breach---reports
story: A Labour MP is no longer in a frontbench role after being caught breaking lockdown rules, according to reports.Rosie Duffield, MP for Canterbury, is no longer a Labour whip after she met her partner while they were living separately, in breach of coronavirus restrictions, the Mail on Sunday said.The paper says that she met her married partner for a long walk in her constituency in April, and that the MP also did not deny he visited her constituency house.EXC: Labour whip Rosie Duffield quits over lockdown loverhellip pic XgxpBbYRmdash MoS_PoliticsMay , Ms Duffield, , told the Mail that the pair observed the two-metre social distancing rules, but these incidents were before meetings between people from dferent households was allowed.The pair are now thought to be living in the same property and her partner separated from his we.In a statement Ms Duffield said: ldquoMy partner and I have been attempting to navigate a dficult personal situation as responsibly as possible. I apologise that during that process, we breached the guidelines.ldquoA relationship breakdown is dficult at the best of times, let alone during a pandemic.ldquoI hope people can understand why I took the steps I did and know that I take responsibility for the breaches that occurred and for which I apologise..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Labour frontbencher no longer in role after lockdown breach  u reports

title: north-berwick-teen-signs-edinburgh-rugby
story: Ben Muncaster, from North Berwick, was one of three signings completed by the capital side last Friday.The back-row moves from Leicester Tigers, where he spent four years as part of the Premiership sidersquos academy.The -year-old said: ldquoIrsquom extremely excited to be joining this club.ldquoI grew up in North Berwick and have always loved Edinburgh as a city, so to be joining the professional rugby team is a dream come true.And he added: ldquoEdinburgh are obviously a very strong team with a great culture.ldquoThey have some exceptional players that I have looked up to for many years.ldquoIrsquoll hopefully try and learn from them as much as I can, certainly in the back row.ldquoIt is such an honour to have been given an opportunity like this, I am very grateful for it, and I want to make the absolute most of it.The teenager, who attended Loretto School, Musselburgh, joins Edinburgh alongside fellow Scotland age-grade players Nathan Chamberlain, who moves from Bristol Bears, and Dan Gamble, who has signed from Heriotrsquos Rugby.Richard Cockerill, head coach at Edinburgh Rugby, was pleased to sign the trio.He said: ldquoItrsquos hugely important that we continue to develop and nurture young Scottish talent, so itrsquos brilliant that wersquove been able to sign three very impressive age-grade players.ldquoBen has come through the ranks at Leicester and has consistently improved his game year after year.ldquoHe will only get better being involved and training with a talented back-row group here at Edinburgh.Muncaster has previously represented Scotland during the under-s Six Nations.Previously speaking to the Leicester Tigers website, he said: ldquoI lived near my local club when I was a kid and so itrsquos no surprise I started playing when I was about four or five.ldquoMy dad enjoys watching but never really played ndash I joined my local rugby club and loved every minute of it.

title: blow-musselburgh-racing-hopes
story: Bosses at the East Lothian track had hoped to hold races behind closed doors on Saturday, June , as the industry looks to restart under restrictions.Groundstaff at thetownrsquos award-winning racecourse, who have been furloughed, were expected to temporarily resume work this month to prepare the track for the anticipated fixture.And East Lothian MP Kenny Macaskill added his voice to a letter to Scottish sports minister Joe FitzPatrick, MSP, urging him to allow Scotlands racecourse to host fixtures as soon as possible.Bill Farnsworth, general manager, was due on Monday to bring a report to MRACwhich oversees course governance, setting out hopes of a restart in early June.However, the BHA released its provisional fixture list for the restart yesterdayand all the racing proposed is in England.The BHA said thatGovernment restrictions eased at the end of the month, it intended to start behind-closed-door racing at Newcastle on June  with  meetings at seven tracks planned for the first eight days of racing.After a single meeting on June  there will be at least two meetings each day with three ndash one each in the north, south and midlands ndash scheduled from Saturday June  to Monday June  inclusive.There will be no regional restrictions on runners competing at any meetings.Mr Farnsworth had hoped Musselburgh would be allowed to take part in the behind closed doors fixtures in June after pointing out how the industry was ready to go.He said: ldquoIf horseracing resumes in June, we hope to stage Musselburghrsquos scheduled fixture on Saturday,June  butthe advice is that June is too early to stage horseracing in Scotland, we will wait until for the appropriate time and for the greenlight from the UK and Scottish Governments.Horse-racing ed in France this week giving hope to trainers that Britain will not be far behind.A joint letter to Scottish Sports Minister Joe Fitzpatrick, MSP, from East Lothian MP Kenny MacAskill and MPs Allan Dorans, Angela Crawley and Pete Wishart, who represent racecourses in Hanmilton, Ayr and Perth urges a quick restart to racing when safe to do so.It says: ldquoRacing finds itself in a unique position compared to other Scottish sports in that our equine athletes, cherished so highly by those in the industry, have remained in training during thepandemic and will therefore be able to come back on shorter notice than the human athletes inother sports.ldquoWhen it is safe to do so, ato racing is the best way of getting the economic cogs of theindustry turning once more, and kickstart the benefits to the Scottish economy that horseracingbrings, even in a behind closed doors environment.ldquoTherefore, we ask that you please accelerateyour talks with Scottish racing to ensure that a risk managedcan take place as soon aspossible and that ato racing behind closed doors in Scotland does not get unduly delayedcompared to the rest of the United Kingdom.

title: new-town-top-low-carbon-location
story: The local authority has lodged its vision for the future with Scottish Ministers as they prepare to create a new National Policy Framework .But it has warned its ambitions must not be sacriced in a rush to kickstart the economy as the nation comes out of lockdown.In an opening statement to their submission, officials expressed concern that new developments may lose sight of the long-term ambition they have for the county.They tell the Scottish Government: ldquoThe current challenges brought about by coronavirus may have lasting effects on the economy.ldquoWhile demand for new development will , it is important that, in the short term, standards in new development are not prejudiced to stimulate growth.ldquoThe ambitions around climate change, ecology, health and well-being, equality, connectivity, inclusive growth and place-making remain.East Lothian Council wants the National Development designation given to the former Cockenzie Power Station site in previous frameworks to be expanded to include the new town of Blindwells which is underway on nearby land, in the new NPF.The council believes that National Development status for the wider area including nearby Blindwells would support ambitions for sustainable growth and an emerging vision for the area to be an influential, innovative, healthy and carbon neutral location.And they say the larger site could become one of Scotlands top ten low carbon locations.While the boundaries of the area are still to be finalised it could stretch out to cover existing communities of Tranent, Prestonpans, Cockenzie and Port Seton and Longniddry.Councillor Norman Hampshire, East Lothian Council spokesperson for Environment, said it was important the county continued to plan for the future during the Covid- outbreak.And he said it was important the ambitions set out before the lockdown continued to be at the heart of decisions made.He said: ldquoWe are ambitious for East Lothian and want to see it remain as a great place in which to live and work, which is well connected with good employment opportunities and sustainability principles at its heart.The local authority has asked Scottish Ministers to designate an area known as The Blindwells, Cockenzie and Climate Change Zone, as a National Development.Councillor Hampshire said: ldquoWe want to see the new settlement at Blindwells developed as a fantastic community in which to live and work.ldquoIt should be a zero emissions community embracing climate change objectives and embracing blue green infrastructure and bioersity.ldquoThe former Cockenzie Power Station site offers signicant opportunity in terms of economic development and employment and work continues to understand its potential.ldquoIn our proposal for a National Development, we are suggesting that a Climate Change Zone is created between these sites, and including parts of, neighbouring communities and sites.ldquoWe believe this wider area, part of the former East Lothian coalfield, could be one of Scotlandrsquos top  locations for low carbon, sustainable inclusive growth and we are determined to grasp the opportunity.ldquoWe are making our case in a submission to the Scottish Government and will be carrying out public engagement on the extent of our vision for the area in due course.

title: edf-donates-3-000-face-masks-crossreach
story: CrossReach, which provides social care services on behalf of the Church of Scotland, has received , face masks from EDF Energy, operators of Torness Power Station.The masks will be used to ensure that staff and residents are protected during the Covid- outbreak.Torness Power Station, near Dunbar, along with its sister station in North Ayrshire and EDFrsquos office in East Kilbride, have each given , masks.CrossReach previously had a facility on Dunbarrsquos Bayswell Road, before it moved to Aldhammer House, Prestonpans.Elspeth McPheat, one of CrossReachrsquos care home managers, said: ldquoIt is amazing how kind and thoughtful people are being.ldquoIt means so much to know that, as social care workers, you are loved and cared for by others when you are loving and caring for those in your care.Rob Guyler, EDFrsquos chief financial officer, said: ldquoWe want to be able to do our bit to support people in the community during these dficult times so we are happy to make this donation.

title: tributes-paid-british-legion-loses-two-members
story: Chairman of the branch Edward OrsquoConnor died on May , at Tranent Care Home, where he was being cared for after suffering a minor stroke.Mr OrsquoConnor, , was described by branch secretary Andrew Davie as an active member who was always involved in ious s in the club, often officiating in sports and competitions such as golf, bowling, fishing, dominoes and darts.Mr Davie said Mr OrsquoConnor had also been the first to join a recently created area of the British Legion, Edinburgh, Lothians and Borders. He carried out his duties as chairman all over Scotland representing the new area.Mr Davie said: ldquoHe will be missed by all the members, as he was always in the club. His long service in the RAF, home and abroad will be remembered.Mr OrsquoConnor leaves one daughter, Sharon.The branch also lost management committee member Alistair Marshall in March.Mr Marshall was well known for collecting thousands of pounds for Poppyscotland and acting as standard bearer for the Royal British Legionat ceremonial events.Mr Marshall, who was , served in the Royal Engineers.Mr Davie said: ldquoAlistair was involved in doing many things when on the committee. As a dedicated doorman at the weekend he made sure everybody behaved themselves. At other events he was a collector for Poppyscotland, especially during Armistice Remembrance, raising many thousands of pounds.ldquoHe was also a standard bearer, carrying out his duties at ceremonial events for RBL and at the passing away of our many comrades, at the graveside and crematoriums.ldquoTo his we Sylvia and stepchildren Karen and Bob, we send our deepest sympathy. He will be sadly missed by all his comrades.

title: seamstress-schoolgirl-sews-masks-ve-day-bunting
story: Niamh McMath, , a primary six pupil at Cockenzie Primary School, is making the masks using a sewing machine she received for Christmas one year, after completing sewing classes.Mum Marie, who lives with Niamh on North Seton Park, said: ldquoShe is making them herself as she got sewing lessons. She just loved them and then got a sewing machine for Christmas.ldquoShersquos really good at it and has made lots of things since the schools have been off shersquos made me a peg bag and a little pouch that can go around my wrist to store my phone in when Irsquom out walking the dog.ldquoI donrsquot know how she does it all.Niamhrsquos younger sister Orla helps by cutting the material and preparing it for production.The material she is using to make them was bought for her by friends and family when she received her sewing machine.A lack of elastic means Niamh is using string, which she finger-knits to make the loops that secure the mask around the wearerrsquos ears.Marie said: ldquoShe saw something in the news about people starting to making their own masks and also the schools making things like visors and she was inspired by that and thought she could make them herself.Niamh sourced a pattern she could refer to and, as there is no printer in the house, drew out the pattern herself.Marie said: ldquoShe made the first one all by herself and when she knew the process enough she explained it to my younger daughter.In about two weeks, Niamh has made roughly  masks, handing them out to friends and family who live nearby.Marie said: ldquoShersquos really talented at it.ldquoA couple of people we have given them to have offered some money but we said to donate it to charity.ldquoItrsquos a challenge to fit things in around school work.ldquoShe made bunting for the front of the house for VE Day, so that took up a bit of time, but she is back to making masks as usual.

title: proud-owner-eisenhowers-autograph
story: To mark the th anniversary of VE Day amidst the Covid- lockdown, Adrian McDowell, who lives on Promenade, was inspired to to publicly share, through the Musselburgh Courier, the story of a programme signed by General Dwight D. Eisenhower, Supreme Commander of the Allied Expeditionary Force in Europe.In , General Eisenhower, who went on to become US President, was made a Freeman of the City of Belfast and Mr McDowellrsquos late uncle John, then Assistant Town Clerk of the city, was present at the ceremony.Mr McDowell, acting president of Musselburgh Horticultural Society, said: ldquoMy late uncle John, who retired as Assistant Town Clerk but who was then a young man, asked the general to autograph his copy of the programme and I have it proudly framed.In a twist of fate, Mr McDowell also met American navy top brass when he was Town Clerk in Bangor in .The honourable John H Dalton, US Secretary of the Navy, visited the town in Northern Ireland to see the pier Eisenhower left to go out into Belfast Lough and board the battleship USS Texas ndash part of the Western Bombardment Fleet getting ready to depart for the D Day Normandy landings. Mr Dalton was shown a commemorative plaque by Mr McDowell.Mr McDowell also played host to the late Admiral William J Crowe, who was Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff under President Bill Clinton, when he was US Ambassador to Great Britain.Mr McDowell said: ldquoThe th anniversary of VE Day reminded me of General Dwight D. Eisenhowerrsquos visit to Bangor in May , many years before I was to become Chief Executive and Town Clerk of the Borough.He explained: ldquoBangor Bay had a strategic role in the Normandy Landings ndash Operation Overlord. Many warships lay at anchor under the command of US Rear Admiral Morton L. Deyo.These included the ,-ton battleship Texas together with the US warships Arkansas, Baldwin and Nevada, which had been badly damaged at Pearl Harbor. Royal Navy ships included Bellona, Black Prince, Enterprise and Erebus. French ships included the cruiser Montcalm and the George Leygues.ldquoAltogether, around , men were aboard the ships. They were all part of the Armada under Rear Admiral Kirk, Commander of the Western Naval Task Force which would carry out major bombardment of German Forces overlooking the Normandy beaches.ldquoBallyholme Beach, situated close to Bangor, was used by landing craft preparing for the landings at Omaha and Utah beaches. Across Belfast Lough and nearly opposite Bangor is the town of Carrickfergus, where the US Rangers were based at Sunnylands Camp to receive intensive commando training, as their task was to scale the Pointe du Hoc ndash the height of a -storey building ndash under intense fire.ldquoSo, as the ships were making ready to sail for D-Day on June , General Eisenhower, or lsquoIke,rsquo as he was affectionately known, visited Bangor in May to go on board a number of ships to wish those sailing Godspeed.ldquoWhen the war was over, he was invited to Belfast to be made a Burgess of the City in recognition of his brilliant leadership as Supreme Allied Commander of Allied Expeditionary Forces in Europe.

title: shielding-runner-takes-garden-half-marathon
story: Stephen Ferguson, , who has asthma, decided to undertake the challenge as he is currently lsquoshieldingrsquo for  weeks after receiving advice from the NHS amidst the Covid- pandemic.He is no stranger to half marathons, having completed three in the past ndash Glentress Trail, Edinburgh and, most recently, Stirling.This time round he is planning to take his treadmill outside on June , and hopes to finish his lsquogardenrsquo half marathon ndash . miles ndash in about two hours.He might even attempt the full marathon distance of . miles in four hourshe can raise enough money for First Step, which celebrates its th anniversary this year.Mr Ferguson, who works with the Royal Bank of Scotland in Haddington, lives on Musselburghrsquos Galt Crescent, near First Step in Galt Avenue, and was inspired to take on the fundraising challenge as his three-year-old son Cormac enjoys attending its nursery.He said: ldquoMy we and son also attended baby classes there, so, from when he was a newborn, he has been involved with First Step.ldquoAll the staff there are amazing and it is more like a family than a nursery. My son gets so excited about going there on a daily basis to see his friends and teachers.ldquoI have seen first hand what First Step does for the community. They are a vital asset to Musselburgh and the surrounding areas.Originally from Omagh in Northern Ireland, Mr Ferguson has lived in Scotland since October , and married his we Louise last October.He also has a step daughter, Aaliyah, who is approaching her th birthday.He said: ldquoAt the moment I am shielding for  weeks, as advised to by the NHS.ldquoI felt this would be a good opportunity to do something worthwhile and raise some money for charity. I know a lot of smaller charities may be struggling now so itrsquos a no brainer really.His past half marathons have raised pound for Asthma UK, a charity close to his heart, and pound for Marie Curie because of the care his late aunt received from its nurses.He is being helped with his training by Junior Burton of JB Combat Bootcamp, Wallyford.Mr Ferguson explained: ldquoJunior Burton and JB Combat Bootcamp have supported me through all these events and helped me improve my quality of le through my fitness, which has improved my asthma undoubtedly.ldquoHe has set me up with an online training plan and has given me extra work to do to help with my marathon training.ldquoI have attended Juniorrsquos bootcamp for around five years now.Mr Ferguson has set a fundraising target of pound, adding: ldquoI would love to smash that and raise at least pound,.First Step was set up in  by a group of local parents who wanted somewhere safe and comfortable where they could meet and their children could play.The initiative has developed its services to meet local needs while continuing to be managed by a community-led management committee and employing a staff team to support local families.To donate to Mr Fergusonrsquos challenge, go to justgiving crowdfunding stephen-ferguson-

title: lockdown-pubs-deliver-1-000-free-meals
story: Jack Robertson took over The Coalgate in Ormiston last year and has been providing the meals alongside his cousin Grant Laurenson, , who owns The Foresters, in PathheadThey have been delivering meals to Tranent and Pencaitland, as well as Ormiston, but people can also collect them from The Coalgate every Thursday, between noon and pm.Jack, , said: ldquoWe just did it off our own back and want to help people that we know who need it.ldquoIrsquom shocked at how many people are struggling for a hot meal itrsquos really upsetting. We want to do what we can while we can.Some of Jackrsquos staff have been coming into work and preparing the meals, while sticking to distancing and health and safety guidelines.They started off with soup and stovies but are now branching out into other foods such as macaroni, with the aim of giving people at least one hearty, home-cooked meal a day.So far, more than , meals have been provided.Jack said: ldquoThe amount of people we have been helping is really good, itrsquos really rewarding.ldquoThe number of meals keeps going up and itrsquos keeping me busy.ldquoI canrsquot believe the response and the number of people getting in touch, but Irsquom still worried we are missing people out thatrsquos my main concern.ldquoThe community has been fantastic and is helping each other out.He has also been dropping off shopping and checking in on people while doing his rounds.Morrisons in Portobello also donated some food items so food parcels could be made for those who are struggling during the ongoing crisis.Anyone who would like to use the service, or recommend someone  who could benefit from it, are asked to message The Coalgate on Facebook at www.facebook thecoalgate or call   on a Wednesday or Thursday.

title: compass-school-pupils-put-colourful-display-chas
story: Children, parents and staff at the Haddington school held a Rainbow Fun Day earlier this month in aid of CHAS .Everyone who took part wore as many bright colours as they could find at home, and sent in photographs to the school, where they were arranged into an impressive gallery of colour.At the same time, families were asked to make a donation in support of the charity, which provides the only hospice care for children with le-shortening conditions across Scotland.Mark Becher, headteacher at the West Road school, thanked everyone for taking part.He said: ldquoWe have been overwhelmed by the support that has been provided to this initiative.ldquoAt this time of crisis, the rainbow has become a symbol of hope and of kindness.ldquoWe felt that to take this theme and to build a fun activity around it in which everyone could become involved and, at the same time, raise essential funds for CHAS would be a great way of bringing the school community lsquotogetherrsquo, even though we are all confined to our homes just now.ldquoWe have been truly amazed by the generosity of our families and friends and are so pleased that we have been able to raise such a signicant amount for such a worthy and important cause.With the spread of Covid-, CHAS is having to overcome additional challenges to provide its usual services in a bid to ensure families are not even more isolated. CHAS is working closely with the NHS to continue to provide end of le care in both Rachel House and Robin House it is also launching the worldrsquos first virtual childrenrsquos hospice to ensure it can continue to support families who are self-isolating as well as keep them and CHAS staff as safe as possible.

title: wonderful-world-books-keeps-shielding-kids-entertained-home
story: Families with vulnerable children who are shielding at home throughout Edinburgh and the Lothians are having hundreds of books delivered to their doorsteps thanks to a new charity partnership.Edinburgh Childrenrsquos Hospital Charityndash which supports the Royal Hospital for Sick Children ndash has teamed up with Edinburgh City Libraries to help children and their siblings feed their imaginations while shielding for  weeks.Caroline Leishman is among those benefiting from the partnership as she stays in her Tranent home with son Finley.She said: ldquoFinley was diagnosed with leukaemia in October .ldquoHe was about two when he was diagnosed and he had to undergo nine months of intense chemotherapy.ldquoHe is now on what is called maintenance and he still gets chemotherapy every day at home but it is a gentler cycle. He goes into hospital once every few weeks and his chemotherapy is due to finish at the end of January .With libraries currently closed, Edinburgh City Libraries and Information Services has made available to ECHC a Book Bus filled with about , books for children and young people.The bus is stationed at the charityrsquos office, where volunteer delivery drivers collect book packages and deliver them to local families known to the Sick Kids hospital.Caroline, , said the delivery of books had been ldquobrilliant and helped keep Finley and big brothers Zach, eight, and Lucas, , occupied.The Market Loan resident said: ldquoComing up with new and exciting ways to keep everyone occupied and distracted while also looking after a clinically vulnerable child becomes a little bit harder as each week goes by.ldquoIt was such a relief when the book parcel from ECHC arrived on our doorstep.ldquoThe kids were so excited to open it and discover all the new books they had to read, which gave us some much needed breathing space!ldquoBooks are such a wonderful resource for children who are shielding. They let their imaginations run wild so they can go on all sorts of fantastic adventures without ever leaving the safety of home.Caroline said Finley loved sitting on her knee for her to read to him, while Zach was starting to enjoy David Walliamsrsquo books and Lucas had read the Harry Potter series.Roslyn Neely, CEO of ECHC, said books were a powerful tool for youngsters.She said: ldquoWe know the power of storytelling and the benefits that brings to children in hospital so wersquore positive it will have the same effect in the home.ldquoWe believe that nothing should get in the way of being a child. Even though they canrsquot physically be out and about in the world right now, children have a huge appetite for adventure and therersquos a whole world of creativity and magic in their imaginations.All books ed to the Book Bus will be held on board for  hours for infection control before being recirculated.The charity is also distributing emergency care packs of food and essential supplies, toiletries and arts and activity items.Donations to ECHCrsquos Covid- appeal can be made at echcharity.org support-us covid--appeal

title: communities-gifford-haddington-macmerry-gladsmuir-ormiston-pencaitland-tranent-elphinstone-offering-support-covid-19
story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at six of the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.Gford. Picture: Google MapsGfordIN GIFFORD, the team are beginning to prepare for a possible ease of lockdown and subsequent impact on the resilience efforts, with some volunteers likely toto their day jobs.The Soup and a Smile service continues, with more people coming forward, and the community council hopes to include a copy of the Courier in its deliveries for those not already receiving one.Community council chairperson Joanne Allen said: ldquoOur single point of contact , Adam, and deputy SPoC, Wendy, are leading on work to look at how our resilience network can continue to operatelockdown restrictions ease.ldquoThis may mean that many of our volunteersto work or education family networks may want to step back in while health advice may change.ldquoFor many of our households ndash especially those that are high risk ndash there may be no change for quite some time and we need to be prepared to continue to support them in whatever way they are comfortable with.ldquoItrsquos important that we consider these issues now. Adam and Wendy had already created our resilience plan which was adapted to deal with Covid-.We will be contacting our volunteers to better understand how any changes will affect them personally and their involvement in the resilience work.Contact detailsAnyone who needs support or wants to help can contact: Jo Allen, on   or chairgfordcc@gmail Adam White, on   or adamjswhite@outlook Wendy Ferguson, on   or wendyferguson.wf@gmail or The Rev Aniko Schuetz Bradwell, on   or anikoschuetzbradwell@churchofscotland.org.ukHaddingtonHaddingtonNEW friendships and new relationships are being formed during the coronavirus pandemic.Volunteers throughout Haddington have been offering to help people in need during the last eight weeks.Chris McEwan, vice-chairman of the townrsquos community council, praised the efforts of people throughout the town in what has been a dficult situation.He said: ldquoI cannot believe how well the town is pulling together. We are doing a lot of good things and a lot of volunteers are right into a regular pattern with people they are looking after.ldquoSome of them are saying they are going to continue doing it eventhis completely goes away. New friendships and relationships have been struck up.The resilience group has been working hard alongside other organisations in the town to help people who are needing assistance.That has included joining forces with Haddington Rotary Club and Our Community Kitchen to help deliver copies of the Courier to people who are unable to get out to shops.Chris highlighted that social distancing was not only impacting upon peoplersquos physical health but also their mental health.He said: ldquoWe have had a lot of people doing kindness telephone calls as well. Our Community Kitchen are doing that as well and we have got people phoning up just trying to alleviate the boredom and isolation for people who are really struggling.ldquoWe have had people wanting people to come round for a coffee and we had somebody wanting someone to take her out in her wheelchair.ldquoIt is one of the most heartbreaking things but you cannot really do that.Volunteers have been assisting in whatever manner they can, from picking up shopping and prescriptions to dog walking and even trying to find gardeners to help people who cannot take care of their garden during the lockdown.Chris has also been making special visors for businesses that hope to be starting up again in the near future.At the same time, the townrsquos community council is keeping its website updated with information about the coronavirus and other assistance on offer.Contact detailsFor more information, go to www.haddingtoncc.org.uk or call    between am and pm.Macmerry. Picture: Google MapsMacmerry and GladsmuirIT HAS been business as usual for the resilience team in Macmerry and Gladsmuir, who hope to deliver activity packs to adults in the next couple of weeks and have also received praise from the local MSP.Stevie Sutherland, one of the co-ordinators, said that the teamrsquos hot meals service is still ongoing and volunteers continue to help with tasks such as shopping, prescription uplts and Post Office visits.In the past couple of weeks, about  packs were handed out as part of the resilience teamrsquos pom pom initiative, which aims to brighten up the village, as well as peoplersquos lives, and is a way to thank all key workers.Stevie said that about four or five pom poms can be made from one pack.Ribbons have been placed across both villages, outside the school gates, on several trees and outside the playpark in Gladsmuir.People who make a pom pom can then tie it to these ribbons as part of the display.Some people have also taken to making their own displays in their gardens.Reaction to the pom poms has so far been positive.In the coming weeks, adult activity packs will be delivered, including things such as puzzles, adult colouring books and craft items, to keep people entertained during lockdown.Funding for the craft packs came from the Coalfields Regeneration Trust.The resilience team also received a recent donation of , bars of soap, with the soap also being included in the activity packs.Iain Gray, East Lothianrsquos MSP, has also donated items to the group.Stevie said he was in Gladsmuir decorating the village with ribbons when Mr Gray and his we approached him.Stevie said: ldquoHe said it was a really good idea and askedI could make use of ious items of kidsrsquo toys. There is a wide spread of things.The items will be given to children in the local area.Contact detailsMore information is available on the resilience grouprsquos Facebook and Twitter pages, atfacebook groups  andtwitter MacmerryTeamOrmiston. Picture: Google MapsOrmistonTHE great work being done by residents in Ormiston continues as people find ways to help make le easier for others.From washing cars to delivering birthday surprises, volunteers have been making everyone proud.Community council chairman Scott Gillies said: ldquoA big thank you goes to Lewis Ward, from Saltire Mobile Valeting, who has been busy.ldquoHe power-washed all the bus shelters and visited the ambulance centre in Haddington and gave all the staff rsquos cars a free wash.ldquoWe have had one volunteer who found out one of our residents, who was shielding, was turning .ldquoSo they delivered balloons and a card when they were delivering them their lunch. She was delighted!ldquoAnother volunteer carried a large bag of compost to a resident who is  and still loves working in his garden. He has his garden looking fantastic and was very grateful.ldquoI think one of the main things that has come out of this situation is that community spirit has been strengthened.ldquoAndrea Reay, one of our volunteers, said she has really enjoyed getting to know some of her neighbours she hadnrsquot met before and gets a lot of satisfaction knowing you have brightened up someonersquos day by getting them some shopping and having a wee chat on the doorstep.ldquoResident Sandra Colquhoun said her volunteer, Lisa Cunningham, has been a lsquoGodsendrsquo and canrsquot thank her enough for what she has done for her.Contact detailsThe resilience team of volunteers are there to help and anyone in Ormiston can contact them on   between am and pm seven days a week, or email Ormistoncrteam@hotmail.Pencaitland. Picture: Google MapsPencaitlandPENCAITLAND residents have set up a Facebook page for those who would like to volunteer to help ldquo Covid- infections overstretch local services and we need people on the ground to help out fellow locals.The community were also given a batch of hand sanitiser by Glenkinchie Distillery, which was shared by volunteers with the Farsquoside resilience team to distribute to volunteers across Tranent, Elphinstone, Macmerry, Ormiston and Pencaitland.Local residents have been encouraged for some weeks to avoid visiting in person the villagersquos shops and to contact the staff via telephone or email to arrange home deliveries.Shoppers are asked to contact Karim Hassam at the Spar on   or message him via Facebook at www.facebook karim.hassam.Mari Fraser in the Granny Shop is also available on   and via Messenger at www.facebook mari.fraser and is happy to organise fresh rolls, milk and newspapers.Contact detailsFor more information, go to www.facebook groups Tranent. Picture: Google MapsTranent and ElphinstoneIN TRANENT and Elphinstone, work continues to help those who are vulnerable, most in need, or who require assistance.The resilience effort is being led by the local community council and is overseen by member Mike Falconer, the grouprsquos single point of contact .The calls and enquiries that continue to come in are described by Mike as ldquorepeat business, such as those requiring pick up of their next prescription or next load of shopping.However, new enquiries have still been surfacing and those who require help of any kind are urged to get in touch.As with other groups, Mike is considering how the resilience effort can continue once lockdown restrictions begin to ease.Those who have registered as volunteers will be contacted by Mike and askedthey are still available andtheir circumstances have changed.The resilience team also helps Fundamental Foods and the Pennypit Trust with meal deliveries, as well as the school hub and its meal and lunch deliveries.More than , food packages have been delivered so far.Additionally, those who usually pick up hearing aid batteries from the library can call the Port Seton Centre on   to arrange for them to be delivered.Contact detailsThose who need assistance can call   or email tranentemergencyresponse@gmail

title: day-centre-receives-holyrood-recognition
story: Harlawhill Day Centrersquos efforts during the coronavirus pandemic were highlighted by the countyrsquos MSP, Iain Gray.The facility had to close its doors on March  due to the global pandemic but Mr Gray felt it was important to recognise the efforts being made by staff and volunteers.The centre, on the townrsquos East Loan, has continued to offer a range of support to members during the pandemic, including organising socially distanced street celebrations outside membersrsquo homes to help mark VE Day and delivering special afternoon tea packages and other food and treats to help keep their spirits up during lockdown.Mr Gray, who lodged a motion at Holyrood highlighting the facility, told the Courier: ldquoHarlawhill Day Centre has always been a special place, very much at the heart of the community in Prestonpans.ldquoIt was a very sad day when it had to close its doors to members back in March. However, the innovative ways they have found to stay connected to service users really exemplies the strong sense of community that has been so evident across East Lothian during the pandemic.ldquoThe staff and volunteers at Harlawhill have gone to great s to maintain the superb care and support they give to members and I am pleased to be able to mark their dedication, as well as that of other local day centres, at Holyrood and thank them for everything they have continued to do to help people over the past few weeks.The motion at Scottish Parliament included the lines: ldquoThat the Parliament commends everyone at the Harlawhill Day Centre in Prestonpans for their dedication in continuing to care for service users, despite having to close the facility during the COVID- lockdown...ldquo...And thanks the staff and volunteers at Harlawhill, and all of East Lothianrsquos other day centres, for the care and support that they are continuing to provide to older people during the Covid- pandemic.

title: aldi-introduces-new-shopping-rule-avoid-massive-queues-keep-social-distancing
story: In recent weeks, queues have been forming outside stores as new measures were introduced to stop the spread of the coronavirus.The retailer is now implementing an automatic traffic light system at entrances, which starts this week following a successful trial.Traffic lights will signal when customers can enter stores based on inidual store customer limits that are in line with two-metre social distancing rules.Richard Thornton, Communications Director at Aldi said: ldquoThe protection and safety of our customers and employees is our top priority and this new system is an accurate and effective way to allow us to control customer numbers in stores.ldquoThe systemrsquos trial was well received by our customers and we will be gradually rolling this new social distancing measure out nationwide from this week.NHS and blue light worker priority access remains in place.These workers are encouraged to go to the front of the queue and other customers will be asked to continue to respect this.The traffic light system will run alongside the current measures already in place at all Aldi stores to ensure social distancing.This includes protective screens at checkouts, distancing markers on shop floors, sanitisation stations for customers as well as signage to offer clear guidance on how to shop safely.Stores are also encouraging one customer per trolley where possible.

title: glasgow-weather-mini-heatwave-24c-weekend-lockdown-set-ease

Today and tomorrow the highest temperatures will be in the South East, but as the week goes on the peak of the warmth will transfer north and west #StayHomeSaveLives # StayAlert pic TYoSNMzyaRSpeaking on Monday, the First Minister said that ldquoeven as we glimpse a possible end to some lockdown restrictions it is ldquomore important than ever to follow the measures that remain in place.ldquoAs we start to lt these restrictions there is a genuine danger that the virus will start to spread again a bit more quickly, she said.ldquoThe way in which we ensure that doesnrsquot happen ndash and that way in which we enable even more restrictions to be lted in future ndash is to continue to follow whatever public health guidance is in place at the time.

title: coronavirus-scotland-explained-five-simple-charts-tables

with  deaths .In Ayrshire and Arran there have been  deaths , and  in Lothian .This graph sets out the number of coronavirus-related deaths in each age group.The most number of deaths, %, come in the + age group - which equated to  since the outbreak began.On the opposite end of the scale, there have been  deaths of people aged -.The majority of coronavirus-linked deaths across Scotland in the week to May  were in care homes at %, down from % the previous week.The number of deaths in care homes also fell for a fourth week in a row, down by  in a week to .The NRS figures also show % of registered deaths involving coronavirus between May  and  were in hospitals, up from % the previous week, while % were at home or in non-institutional settings, down from % the week before.This final table outlines the number of coronavirus deathsper council area - setting out the dferent locations for each.Other insitutions in this case includes clinics, medical centres, prisons and schools.This graph shows, as expected, Glasgow City Council has recorded the most deaths so far with .On the other end of the table, Orkney has only recorded two deaths.Speaking about the NRS figures, Nicola Sturgeon told MSPs at Holyrood: ldquoThese trends, which have now been sustained for over four weeks, do definitely give us grounds for encouragement.ldquoThe weekly number of Covid deaths has fallen by more than % from its peak.ldquoExcess deaths have reduced more than three-quarters and deaths in care homes are also falling.She added: ldquoTomorrow, we will take a formal decision on whether to begin cautiously to emerge from lockdown.ldquoAny early steps are likely to focus on outdoor activities and we will provide full information on what businesses should and should not be doing.ldquoBut I stress evensome restrictions are relaxed later this week it will continue to be essential to follow guidance ndash for example, to stay two metres apart from people from other households and to self-isolateyou have symptoms.

title: schoolboy-jacks-lockdown-poem-cheers-everyone
story: Jack Rutherford, , wrote the poem as part of a task set by his Law Primary School teacher Mrs Baxter.Jack read it to his class during a Google classroom online session and his mum Jen told the Courier ldquohis teacher got quite emotional.ldquoJack is just a wee ray of sunshine and is great at cheering everyone up, Jen added.A film of Jack performing his lockdown poem was sent to his gran and grandad Nancy and Ian Sloan, who are isolating in Lockerbie with Jen, and who also loved the poem.Jackrsquos poetic cheer is especially needed by the family during this time: Jackrsquos gran Nancy was diagnosed with oian cancer  months ago, while his dad Peterrsquos father is also unwell in hospital.Peter said: ldquoItrsquos dficult for everyone but we are lucky that we have a garden and some lovely open spaces and are lucky to get out and exercise.Jack is spending lockdown in Dundas Avenue, North Berwick, with dad Peter and big sister Ruby, .Peter added: ldquoHe has bundles of energy. He loves sport and playing rugby, football and tennis and taking the dog for a walk. Hersquos a real outdoor kid and is good with his words. He reads to his two-year-old cousin once a week on Zoom as part of our new lockdown routine.Due to the response to his poetry, Jack is now writing more.The poem, titled Jackrsquos Lockdown Poem, reads:My name is Jack and Irsquom  years old. When Im older there will be a story to be told.In  along came a nasty bug. That meant we werent able to give anyone a hug.I am lucky to be at home with my family and pet. We have a nice garden so we are all set.We can go to the park and the beach. And the hills around us are within easy reach.I get to spend time at home all day long. Irsquom learning ukulele and soon a new song.My garden is growing I water the plants. Sometimes in my jammies and I skip over the ants.Irsquom getting lots of snacks ndash Im really well fed. And I stay up later and later before going to bed.The sun is warm, there is no storm. I hope you stay safe and come to no harm.

title: moments-joy-savoured-lockdown-gently-eased
story: First Minister Nicola Sturgeon is expected to announce this afternoonthe first tentative steps towards a lsquonew normalrsquo with people from other households able to meet socially ndash while maintaining social distance ndash once more and some outdoor sports allowed to resume.The announcement will allow people to be in the company of friends or family for the first time since  days of lockdown sparked by the coronavirus pandemic.East Lothian MP Kenny MacAskill said, for many, itwould be the first time they could celebrate signicant events and comfort each other over loved ones lost during the crisis.He said: ldquoIt is good to see small steps being taken. Hopefully, theyrsquoll allow for people to catch up on moments of joy that have been missed or comfort those who have lost.ldquoItrsquos a long way to go but a welcome start.Across the county, plans are afoot to reopen golf courses, bowling greens and garden centres.The First Minister is also expected to give the green light to construction sites to restart as long as social distancing and personal protective equipmentcan be provided.Schools will open on August  but teaching staff are expected tonext month and some pupils who face transitioning from nursery to P and primary to secondary school are likely to come into their new school at the end of next month.Phase one of the Scottish Governmentrsquos four phase route out of lockdown is expected to be confirmed by the First Minister this afternoonwhen she announces her review of the current lockdown restrictions.Last week Ms Sturgeon set out a range of activities which will be allowed including outdoor recreation, meeting with people from other households and letting people who cannot work from hometo workit can be done safely.Iain Gray, East Lothianrsquos MSP, said there were questions which still needed answered by the Scottish Government.He said: ldquoWhile the lsquoroute maprsquo is understandably flexible in its later stages, we do know that there should be some easing of restrictions this week, including theof some non-contact sport, the reopening of garden centres and recycling facilities, and being able to visit friends or relatives albeit only outside and two metres apart.ldquoAfter more than two months in lockdown this initial easing will come as a relief to many.ldquoHowever, there are still many issues the Scottish Government need to clary about the way forward, including the expansion of testing to implement the test, trace, isolate and support strategy, measures to tackle the ongoing emergency in our care homes and plans for repairing the economy as we move out of lockdown.ldquoWe have only reached this stage because people have obeyed lockdown, and reduced infection. It is so important as those restrictions ease that we do not slip into behaving aswe are back to normal. If we do, infections will rise again, and restrictions will be re-imposed, not eased.East Lothian Council leader Willie Innes thanked members of the public in the county for following the lockdown restrictions and the huge community response to help the most vulnerable people.He said: ldquoDealing with the Covid- emergency is highly likely to remain a signicant challenge for some considerable time to come. The Scottish Government has published its four-phase lsquoroute maprsquo aimed at restarting society while suppressing the virus and has confirmed that some restrictions will begin to be eased from the end of this week.ldquoIt is very clear that, as progress remains fragile, the easing of lockdown restrictions must be taken very gradually and incrementally.ldquoThroughout this period we have been following the national advice and will continue to do so. ldquoOn a practical note I, along with many others, will welcome the reopening of the recycling centres and the ability to meet friends and family albeit on a restricted basis. East Lothianrsquos golf courses are being prepared to reopen with changes made to ensure safety for staff and members is a priority.Bill Axon, chief executive of enjoyleisure, which runs golf courses at Musselburgh Old Links and Winterfield, Dunbar, said new policies include sneeze guards, masks and visors for staff and asking for flagsticks to remain in place at all times.Mr Axon said: ldquoFor enjoyleisure, the safety of customers and colleagues come first.ldquoWe have been constantly monitoring the latest Government advice surrounding Covid-, and along with guidance issued by the Scottish Golf and the RA, both courses have been adapted to comply with current social distancing policies.ldquoWe ask all of our customers to adhere to the measures in place, so that we can continue to enjoy golf now and into the future.Indoor sports facilities are not included in the phase one changes but Mr Axon said enjoyleisure, which also oversees the majority of them in the county, would continue to follow government guidance on when they are allowed to reopen.About  per cent of staff with enjoyleisure had been furloughed, with no redundancies made.Mr Axon said there was no alternative work which could be offered and highlighted that the impact of the coronavirus had ldquonot been insignicant in terms of income, with income levels dropping by about pound, per month.Malcolm Duck, who is part of the steering group involved in Scotlandrsquos Golf Coast, said: ldquoWe are waiting for the First Minister to give us the date.ldquoThe impression is it will be Friday but I am not sure that has been confirmed yet. Golf clubs will be able to open and people will be able to get on golf courses.Mr Duck encouraged people to visit the  courses across the county when it was safe to do so.He said: ldquoThe weather is great and it will be great to be able to go out on the golf courses.Billy Mellors, county bowls development officer, said not all bowling clubs in East Lothian would be opening their doors and restrictions would be in place.He said: ldquoDepending on what Nicola Sturgeon says on Thursday, bowling clubs are free to open on Friday with some pretty severe restrictions in place.That will include limiting the number of people allowed on the green at any one time, as well as clubhouses not opening.Brian Whellans, president of Haddington Bowling Club, said club bosses were meeting online todayto discuss a way forward.He said: ldquoThe bowling green is ready to go. Wersquove got a greenkeeper that is paid on a monthly basis. Grass still grows and needs to be cut and things are ready to go when it is safe to do so.Garden centres across East Lothian have been operating a home delivery service during lockdown, but now preparations are being made for them to reopen their doors as early as Friday.Merryhatton Garden Centre, by East Fortune Dunbar Garden Centre and Strawberry Corner Garden Centre, Wallyford are all poised to re-open.Merryhattonrsquos Helen MacDonald said that she received confirmation from the Horticultural Trade Association that, providing the First Minister gives the green light, she can open tomorrowmorning at am.Merryhattonrsquos cafe will remain closed.She said: ldquoAlthough wersquoll be delighted when wersquore allowed to reopen the garden centre, wersquoll continue to offer both home delivery and click and collect because we understand that some of our customers will have to remain in isolation.To prepare for reopening, the layout of the garden centre has been rearranged to create a ldquoflow system and markers have been placed on the ground, designed to help keep customers safeHelen added: ldquoWe will provide disposable gloves and sanitiser for our customers and there will be a queuing system in place to limit the number of customers at any one time.ldquoTo be fair to all our customers wersquore asking people to shop on their own or in a maximum group size of two. If at all possible, we are asking that only adult customers visit during this critical time.ldquoAlthough wersquore looking forward to seeing our customers again, I have to confess to being a little nervous about re-opening with these measures in place.ldquoHowever, the safety of customers and staff is our priority and we hope that customers will be patient with us whilst we find our feet and adapt.Under the Scottish Governmentrsquos route map to ease lockdown restrictions, outdoor workplaces can resume with ldquophysical distancing measures in place once guidance is agreed, meaning that garden centres can reopen but not their cafes unless it is for takeaway.County recycling centres are due to open to the public on Monday, with social distancing measures introduced.Phase two of the route out of lockdown, which could be introduced at the next review in three weeksrsquo time, could see theof outdoor markets such as Haddington Farmersrsquo Market and more workplaces open as well as the introduction of more social gatherings.Colin Beattie, MSP for Musselburgh, welcomed the phase one plans.Mr Beattie said: ldquoI am pleased with the cautious approach which the Scottish Government is taking towards releasing lockdown.ldquoThe approach is clear and unambiguous compared to the chaos and contradictions south of the border. The absolute priority is protecting lives.ldquoThe economy is certainly going to be our next priority but we can rebuild the economy while we canrsquot bring back someonersquos mum or dadthey contract a terminal case of Covid-. By and large people have respected the lockdown in Scotland and I am confident that we will all continue to respect the phased release of lockdown. It is in all our best interests to do so.Meanwhile, the number of deaths related to Covid- in East Lothian has risen by two in the past week.National Records of Scotland said that the total number of coronavirus-related deaths in the county, up to Sunday, May , was  ndash two more than on May  .Across Scotland, there was a total of , Covid- deaths up to May , a rise of  over the last week.However it was noted this was a decrease of  in the number of deaths related to Covid- recorded in the previous weekrsquos period and the fourth week in a row when the number of deaths recorded had fallen.
